statement:
Suppose $I$ is an open interval on $\mathbb{R}$, and
$f\colon I\to {\mathbb{C}}$ is differentiable at $x\in I$. Then $f$ is
continuous at $x$. Further, if $f$ is differentiable on $I$, then $f$ is
continuous on $I$.

Suppose $x\in I$. Let us show that $f(y)\to f(x)$, when $y\to x$. First,
if $y\in I$ is distinct to $x$, then
$$f(x)-f(y) = \frac{f(x)-f(y)}{x-y} (x-y).$$ Thus, if $f'(x)$ is the
derivative of $f$ at $x$, we have $$\begin{aligned}
\lim_{y\to x} f(x)-f(y) &=& \lim_{y\to x} \frac{f(x)-f(y)}{x-y} (x-y) \\
   &=& \lim_{y\to x} \frac{f(x)-f(y)}{x-y}\  \lim_{y\to x}  (x-y) \\
   &=& f'(x)\  0 \\
   &=& 0,\end{aligned}$$ where the second equality is justified since
both limits on the second line exist. The second claim follows since $f$
is continuous on $I$ if and only if $f$ is continuous at $x$ for all
$x\in I$.
